docs.lead_paragraph: More than 40 million American adults already take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease. Now many more are weighing the pros and cons of daily aspirin use in light of new studies finding that it also may reduce the risk of many cancers and stop the spread of tumors. Six months ago Vanessa Brannan, a 31-year-old Seattle mother of two, learned she had colon cancer and Lynch syndrome, an inherited condition that increases risk of the disease and other cancers. Some of the best data on aspirin's effectiveness against cancer has been found in patients like Mrs. Brannan. In one British study, patients with Lynch syndrome who took aspirin for two years cut their risk of colon cancer in half.

headline.main: The Consumer: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?

docs.abstract: More than 40 million American adults take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease, and the number is expanding in light of recent studies showing that it may reduce the risk of many cancers; science of understanding the relationship between aspirin and cancer remains in its infancy, and doctors remain sharply divided over what is the most effective dosage. Photo (M)

headline.main: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?
headline.print_headline: The Consumer: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?

docs.abstract: Despite recent good news about aspirin reducing the risk of cancers, doctors still don't know how much of it people should take.
docs.snippet: Despite recent good news about aspirin reducing the risk of cancers, doctors still don't know how much of it people should take.

docs.lead_paragraph: A RELATIVELY new field, called interpersonal neurobiology, draws its vigor from one of the great discoveries of our era: that the brain is constantly rewiring itself based on daily life. In the end, what we pay the most attention to defines us. How you choose to spend the irreplaceable hours of your life literally transforms you. All relationships change the brain -- but most important are the intimate bonds that foster or fail us, altering the delicate circuits that shape memories, emotions and that ultimate souvenir, the self.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Diane Ackerman highlights research on how love affects the brain. Drawing (M)1
